awd_titl_txt: WiFiUS: RF Sensing in Internet of Things: When Deep Learning Meets CSI Tensor
awd_abstract_narration:
Internet of Things (IoT) refers to a worldwide network of interconnected uniquely addressable things based on standard communication protocols. In recent years, medical care and healthcare are recognized as one of the most attractive application areas of the IoT, with applications ranging from patient and equipment tracking in medical facilities to health monitoring. The goal of this project is to investigate an IoT healthcare monitoring system, which is likely to continue to grow in popularity as it utilizes IoT in various ways for improving the quality of patient care. The outcomes from this project will significantly improve the state-of-the-art of RF sensing in the IoT, and provide a significant step toward enriched user experience at greatly reduced costs. The educational plan includes developing and enhancing undergraduate and graduate-level courses in the field. The simulation tool and testbed will provide excellent opportunities for students to gain hands-on experience in the cutting-edge technology. Outcomes from this project will be disseminated through publications, presentations, and a project website. The PIs are fully committed to increasing participation from under-represented groups in research, and will continue to further such efforts via outreach, in particular, through collaboration with Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU).

Specifically, this project aims to gain a deep understanding of RF sensing in healthcare IoT by exploiting advanced statistics and learning techniques, and to develop effective algorithms to make healthcare IoT more efficient. This research intends to significantly reduce the cost and improve the accuracy of RF sensing in healthcare IoT with intelligent exploration of CSI tensor and deep learning. The research work falls into the following three interwoven thrusts. (i) RF Sensing in Indoor IoT Environments: to address several fundamental challenges in RF sensing in indoor IoT environments, including developing a stochastic model for CSI based fingerprinting, incorporating nested arrays, and applying deep learning for indoor device-free localization. (ii) RF Sensing for Healthcare: to develop effective solutions for contact-free and long-term vital signs and human behavior monitoring, using RF and inaudible sound signals. (iii) System integration and evaluation: we will integrate the components from the first two thrusts into a healthcare IoT environment to understand the interaction of these components and evaluate the overall system performance.

por.por_cntn:
The expansion of the current Internet with a huge number of interconnected devices (a.k.a. “things”) has been a tremendously growing trend in recent decades, which brings about a variety of significant applications and services that contribute to improving the quality of life in various communities, such as personalized healthcare in smart home, smart automation, and environmental monitoring. In line with this trend, the emerging paradigm of Internet-of-Things (IoT) has been gaining increasing ground. Semantically, IoT refers to a worldwide network of interconnected uniquely addressable things based on standard communication protocols. The basic idea behind IoT is to evolve the currently static Internet into a fully integrated network that not only harvests information from, and interacts with the physical world, but also coordinates the interconnected things to accomplish tasks by letting them to communicate, with the convergence point of creating an intelligent environment. The successful emergence of IoT demands a platform architecture to capture, store, process, and communicate the data received from the environment.

The project includes a coherent set of research activities to address several fundamental problems and challenges arising in healthcare IoT, including RF sensing indoors, vital signs monitoring, leveraging the multimodal CSI data, represented by tensors, and the technique of deep learning. This project involves a complementary mix of theoretical analysis, modeling and simulation, and implementation/experiments that assess the performance benefits of the developed techniques. Our focus has been on common RF sensing problems in wireless IoT systems, using healthcare IoT as an example. During the project years, research has been conducted to address the following problems. Frist, we have addressed several fundamental challenges in accurate RF sensing in indoor IoT environments, including developing a stochastic model and analysis for validating the feasibility and trade-offs for deep learning and CSI based fingerprinting, incorporating nested arrays, an advanced antenna technology, for RF sensing in indoor IoT, and applying deep learning for indoor localization. Second, we have developed effective solutions for contact-free and long-term vital signs and human behavior monitoring, using RF and inaudible sound signals. We explored advanced statistics and learning techniques to extract rich information from CSI tensor, to achieve high accuracy in vital signs monitoring. This also led to effective driving fatigue detection systems based on RFID. Third, we also explored a broader range of related problems, including RF sensing for safe food storage, a deep reinforcement learning based smart congestion control, and developing a deep reinforcement learning based resource allocation/optimization scheme for the constrained backhaul in millimeter-wave networks. Most of the developed schemes have been implemented with off-the-shelf wireless devices and validated with extensive experiments. The testbed/prototypes have also been utilized as a platform for involving undergrads, outreach, and technology transfer.

This project has made great advances in improving the state-of-the-art of IoT and provide a significant step forward in applying machine learning to solving wireless networking problems. The findings have been incorporated into the graduate courses offered at Auburn University. Many graduate students (including one African-American) have been involved in this project, working on various research projects as part of their thesis work. A few undergraduate students have been supported by the NSF research experience for undergrads (REU) program, and K-12 teachers (including one African-American) by the NSF research experience for teachers (RET) program, to work on this project. The research outcomes have been widely disseminated in the conferences and journals in the wireless field as well as the project website.  This project has led to a large number of high-quality publications that have been widely cited, as well as several best paper/demo awards and several US provisional patents. The investigator has worked closely with industrial partners to disseminate the outcomes and enable rapid technology transfer.
